text: The particular circumstances of the case
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant is a British citizen born in 1964 and resident in Willingham. She is represented before the Commission by Mr. Luke Clements, a solicitor practising in Hereford.
label: non-argumentative

text: The facts as submitted by the parties may be summarised as follows.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant is a gypsy by birth.
label: non-argumentative

text: Her family has for many generations been based in the area of South Cambridgeshire near Willingham.
label: non-argumentative

text: Until 1988, the applicant had no fixed abode but travelled in caravans throughout the Willingham area.
label: non-argumentative

text: In 1988 Mr. and Mrs. Buckley (who is the applicant's sister) acquired a one acre site in the Willingham area from a Mr. and Mrs. S., who had applied for and been refused, retrospective planning permission for a single caravan.
label: non-argumentative

text: In May 1988, Mr. and Mrs. Buckley applied retrospectively for planning permission to have one residential caravan on the frontage of their one acre site.
label: non-argumentative

text: Permission was given on a personal temporary basis.
label: non-argumentative

text: In November 1988, a further retrospective application was made for three caravans.
label: non-argumentative

text: These were occupied by the applicant and her three children.
label: non-argumentative

text: Permission was given in January 1989 on a personal temporary basis.
label: non-argumentative

text: On an unspecified date in 1988, the applicant acquired part of the land belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Buckley.
label: non-argumentative

text: In October 1989 on the part of the land acquired by the applicant, there were three caravans occupied by the applicant, her children and her mother.
label: non-argumentative

text: A retrospective planning application in respect of the three caravans was submitted on 4 December 1989.
label: non-argumentative

text: While it was under consideration the fourth caravan occupied by the applicant's brother moved on to the site.
label: non-argumentative

text: The application was refused by the District Council on 8 March 1990 on the basis that adequate provision had been made for gypsy caravans elsewhere, that the planned use of the land would detract from the rural and open quality of the landscape and that the access to the site was too narrow to allow two vehicles to pass.
label: non-argumentative

text: An enforcement notice was issued by the District Council for the caravans to be removed to take effect on 15 May 1990.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant appealed against the enforcement notice to the Secretary of State for the Environment.
label: non-argumentative

text: In a decision dated 16 April 1991 based on an inspector's report, the Secretary of State dismissed the appeal, finding that the objections to the continued use of the site for caravans were so strong on planning and highway safety grounds that the grant of permission could not be justified.
label: non-argumentative

text: He found also that the concentration of gypsy sites in the area had reached the desirable maximum and the need for additional sites for gypsies should not outweigh the planning and highway objections.
label: non-argumentative

text: The inspector also referred to the fact that the applicant had planning permission to station a caravan on an adjoining approved site.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant did not appeal to the High Court since this appeal lies only on points of law and she was advised that no grounds arose in her case.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant was served with a summons for failure to comply with the enforcement notice on 9 September 1991.
label: non-argumentative

text: At the hearing in the Magistrates' Court on 7 January 1992, the applicant pleaded guilty on the advice of her solicitor and was fined £50 with £10 costs.
label: non-argumentative

text: The applicant has not moved and another enforcement notice is imminent.
label: non-argumentative

text: By letter dated 20 May 1993, the Department of the Environment informed the District Council that the Secretary of State had decided to designate the area of South Cambridgeshire under section 12 of the Caravan Sites Act 1968.
label: non-argumentative

text: Designation was granted on the basis of the Council's assurance that they will apply their powers humanely and give sympathetic consideration to applications for gypsy sites.
label: non-argumentative

text: It was noted that a small number of gypsies still remained on unauthorised sites but that, in light of the provision made for sites which is greater than in any other district, it was considered "not expedient for adequate accommodation to be provided for gypsies residing in or resorting to South Cambridgeshire District

text: Provision for gypsy sites
label: non-argumentative

text: Section 16 of the Caravan Sites Act 1968 (the 1968 Act) defines "gipsies" as:
label: non-argumentative

text: persons of nomadic habit of life, whatever their race or origin, but does not include members of an organised group of travelling showmen, or of persons engaged on travelling circuses, travelling together as such.
label: non-argumentative

text: Section 6 of the 1968 Act provides that it shall be the duty of local authorities:
label: non-argumentative

text: ... to exercise their powers...so far as may be necessary to provide adequate accommodation for gipsies residing in or resorting to their area.
label: non-argumentative

text: Pursuant to section 9 of the 1968 Act, the Secretary of State may direct local authorities to provide sites:
label: non-argumentative

text: The Secretary of State may, if at any time it appears to him to be necessary so to do, give directions to any local authority to which subsection 1 of section 6 of this Act applies requiring them to provide pursuant to that section, such sites or additional sites, for the accommodation of such numbers of caravans, as may be specified in the directions; and any such directions shall be enforceable, on the application of the Secretary of State, by mandamus
label: non-argumentative

text: The Secretary of State has made directions to a local authority under section 9 on five occasions.
label: non-argumentative

text: No application has ever been made to the courts to enforce any such directions.
label: non-argumentative

text: Pursuant to Section 12 of the 1968 Act, where the Secretary of State is satisfied that the duty imposed by Section 6 has been carried out, he may designate the area of that local authority as one to which Section 10 applies
label: non-argumentative

text: Section 10 of the 1968 Act provides :
label: non-argumentative

text: Prohibition of unauthorised camping in designated areas
label: non-argumentative

text: In any area designated under the following provisions of this Act as an area to which this section applies it shall be an offence for any person being a gipsy to station a caravan for the purpose of residing for any period
label: non-argumentative

text: on any land situated within the boundaries of a highway;
label: non-argumentative

text: on any other unoccupied land;
label: non-argumentative

text: on any occupied land without the consent of the occupier
label: non-argumentative

text: In proceedings against any person for an offence under this section it shall be a defence to prove that the caravan was stationed on the land in consequence of illness, mechanical breakdown or other immediate emergency and that he removed it (or intended to remove it) as soon as reasonably practicable
label: non-argumentative

text: A person guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding [level 1 on the standard scale]; and if the offence of which he is convicted is continued after the conviction he shall be guilty of a further offence and shall be liable in respect thereof to a fine not exceeding £5 for every day on which the offence is so continued.
label: non-argumentative

text: Section 11 of the Act provides:
label: non-argumentative

text: Orders for removal of unlawfully parked caravans and their occupants
label: non-argumentative

text: In any area to which section 10 of this Act applies, a magistrates' court may, on a complaint made by a local authority, and if satisfied that a caravan is stationed on land within the authority's area in contravention of that section, make an order requiring any caravan (whether or not identified in the order) which is so stationed on the land to be removed together with any person residing in it.
label: non-argumentative

text: An order under this section may authorise the local authority to take such steps as are reasonably necessary to ensure that the order is complied with and in particular, may authorise the authority, by its officers and servants
